ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I hope Dr. Holmes becomes a permanent Yale professor because this course was absolutely excellent. The course design constitutes a final paper, reading notes (not formally graded), being a discussant, a presenter, and two written assignments. It may all seem like a heavy work load, but it is all very tolerable. The readings are fairly heavy, but you can really focus on just a few of them and prepare for the discussions. The class was incredibly small: 5 students. It was targeted at graduate students, but we only had undergraduates. In all, the discussant/present model really facilitates a learning environment. It demands that you be more engaged, and you will learn to re-assess your viewpoints. In the end, the course was rigorous to a degree, but Dr. Holmes most certainly rewarded us well for our efforts.I strongly recommend this class.
I would DEFINITELY recommend this class. It's a lot of work, but totally worth it. You'll learn tons.

Expect a LOT of reading, but the class is amazing. If you are interested in the relationship between the US and Europe, take this course! It's not heavy on theory, allows for ample discussion, and Professor Holmes is outstanding!
